definitions.definition: looking clean and neat; well dressed in fashionable and/or formal clothes

examples.text: I have to be smart for work.
You look very smart in that suit.
She was incredibly smart in navy blue silk.

definitions.definition: clean, neat and looking new and attractive

examples.text: a smart suit
They were wearing their smartest clothes.
She was wearing a smart red coat.
They wear smart blue uniforms.
smart new shoes
The car was a smart two-seater.
The restaurant has a smart new décor.

definitions.sensetop: it is smart to do something
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)(especially North American English)especially British English

examples.text: He is obviously a **smart guy**.
Why do **smart people** do such stupid things?
She's smarter than her brother.
That was a **smart** career **move**.
OK, I admit it was not the **smartest thing** I ever did *(= it was a stupid thing to do)*
He is too ambitious, too smart for his own good.
It's always smart to have a Plan B.
examples.contextForm: it is smart to do something

examples.text: She's smart enough to know what works and what doesn't.
If you're smart, you'll take my advice.
Companies are getting smart about how they use corporate planes.

definitions.definition: controlled by a computer, so that it appears to act in an intelligent way

examples.text: smart bombs
This smart washing machine will dispense an optimal amount of water for the load.
smart restaurants
She mixes with **the smart set** *(= fashionable, rich people)*.
She was one of the smart set in the 1920s.
The reception would be very grand and smart.

definitions.definition: quick and usually done with force

examples.text: He was struck with a smart crack on the head.
We set off at a smart pace.

wordOrigin: Old English smeortan (verb), of West Germanic origin; related to German schmerzen; the adjective is related to the verb, the original sense (late Old English) being ‘causing sharp pain’; from this arose ‘keen, brisk’, which led to the current senses of ‘mentally sharp’ and ‘neat in a brisk, sharp style’.
